contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2010}} {{TWCleanup}} In [[Irish language|Irish]], '''Ollam''' or '''Ollamh''' (anglicised as '''Ollave''' or '''Ollav'''), is a master in a particular trade or skill. In [[Early Irish literature|early Irish Literature]], it generally refers to the highest rank of [[Fili]]; it could also modify other terms to refer to the highest member of any group: thus an ''ollam brithem'' would be the highest rank of judge and an ''ollam [[rí]]'' would be the highest rank of king. In modern Irish, it has come to mean "[[professor]]". There was an official post in ancient Ireland called the "[[Rí]] Ollam" or "Ard Ollam" or [[Chief Ollam of Ireland]]. The holder of the post had a standing equal to the High King of Ireland. [[Ollamh Fodhla]], meaning "great teacher," was used to designate various prominent men throughout history. ==Literary fosterage== In [[Ancient Ireland]], ollams taught children either for payment or for no compensation.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.libraryireland.com/Brehon-Laws/Fosterage.php|title=Fosterage in Ancient Ireland|publisher=Library Ireland|accessdate=2012-06-16}}</ref> ==References== <references/> {{Portal|Ireland}} [[Category:Irish literature]] {{Lit-stub}} {{Ireland-stub}}
